.22 magnum Savage 93, the first rifle I bought.  I added a Tasco 3-9x scope and acquired two 10 round mags.  They are better than the original 5 rounder (threw it away), but they're not perfect.  This gun feeds the first 9 rounds just fine, but the 10th usually doesn't go into the chamber without some fiddling with the finger, putting it into launch position.  These rifles seem to be famous for mags that aren't great, and compared to a lot of stories, these mags are pretty good.  9 good feeds out of 10, if you run the bolt briskly.  The mag springs seem to be just too weak to position that last round for chamber entry.  I wouldn't be surprised if there's an aftermarket replacement mag that's better, but I haven't found it.

Overall, great light rifle for someone who isn't 6'4" and 275 lbs.  

It's in very good condition and I haven't put more than about fifty rounds through it.  I bought it sight unseen and it's physically a bit too small for me.  And I'm a lefty, and right handed bolt operation is harder than I thought it would be.

Not worth shipping/Xfer costs, Houston area is best, I'll meet you somewhere that works.  :-)

The last time out with it, about a year ago, I put twenty rounds into an area the size of a playing card at 100 yards.  Not spectacular grouping, but I have learned I"m not a very good shot with an awkward small rifle.  (I do better with my Savage 110 left hand bolt in .270 Winchester).

The driving spring is captive and is secured to the right side plate at the rear by sliding a conical block into a dovetailed slot. There is no driving spring rod protruding through the back plate.
